dialogue_history.content:
Analyze this financial news and estimate stock price movement probabilities.
Company: Apple Inc. (AAPL)
News Headline: Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) Seems To Use Debt Rather Sparingly
News Content: David Iben put it well when he said, 'Volatility is not a risk we care about. What we care about is avoiding the permanent loss of capital.' When we think about how risky a company is, we always like to look at its use of debt, since debt overload can lead to ruin. Importantly, Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) does carry debt. But the real question is whether this debt is making the company risky.

Why Does Debt Bring Risk?

Debt and other liabilities become risky for a business when it cannot easily fulfill those obligations, either with free cash flow or by raising capital at an attractive price. Ultimately, if the company can't fulfill its legal obligations to repay debt, shareholders could walk away with nothing. However, a more usual (but still expensive) situation is where a company must dilute shareholders at a cheap share price simply to get debt under control. Of course, the upside of debt is that it often represents cheap capital, especially when it replaces dilution in a company with the ability to reinvest at high rates of return. The first thing to do when considering how much debt a business uses is to look at its cash and debt together.

Check out our latest analysis for Apple

What Is Apple's Net Debt?

You can click the graphic below for the historical numbers, but it shows that Apple had US$106.6b of debt in September 2024, down from US$111.1b, one year before. However, because it has a cash reserve of US$65.2b, its net debt is less, at about US$41.5b.NasdaqGS:AAPL Debt to Equity History January 15th 2025

A Look At Apple's Liabilities

According to the last reported balance sheet, Apple had liabilities of US$176.4b due within 12 months, and liabilities of US$131.6b due beyond 12 months. Offsetting this, it had US$65.2b in cash and US$66.2b in receivables that were due within 12 months. So its liabilities outweigh the sum of its cash and (near-term) receivables by US$176.6b.

Of course, Apple has a titanic market capitalization of US$3.51t, so these liabilities are probably manageable. However, we do think it is worth keeping an eye on its balance sheet strength, as it may change over time. Carrying virtually no net debt, Apple has a very light debt load indeed.

We use two main ratios to inform us about debt levels relative to earnings. The first is net debt divided by earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA), while the second is how many times its earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) covers its interest expense (or its interest cover, for short). Thus we consider debt relative to earnings both with and without depreciation and amortization expenses.

Story Continues

Apple has a low net debt to EBITDA ratio of only 0.31. And its EBIT covers its interest expense a whopping 673 times over. So we're pretty relaxed about its super-conservative use of debt. The good news is that Apple has increased its EBIT by 7.8% over twelve months, which should ease any concerns about debt repayment. When analysing debt levels, the balance sheet is the obvious place to start. But ultimately the future profitability of the business will decide if Apple can strengthen its balance sheet over time. So if you want to see what the professionals think, you might find this free report on analyst profit forecasts to be interesting.

Finally, a business needs free cash flow to pay off debt; accounting profits just don't cut it. So we clearly need to look at whether that EBIT is leading to corresponding free cash flow. During the last three years, Apple generated free cash flow amounting to a very robust 90% of its EBIT, more than we'd expect. That positions it well to pay down debt if desirable to do so.

Our View

Apple's interest cover suggests it can handle its debt as easily as Cristiano Ronaldo could score a goal against an under 14's goalkeeper. And that's just the beginning of the good news since its conversion of EBIT to free cash flow is also very heartening. Zooming out, Apple seems to use debt quite reasonably; and that gets the nod from us. After all, sensible leverage can boost returns on equity. When analysing debt levels, the balance sheet is the obvious place to start. But ultimately, every company can contain risks that exist outside of the balance sheet. Be aware that  Apple is showing  2 warning signs in our investment analysis, you should know about...

At the end of the day, it's often better to focus on companies that are free from net debt. You can access our special list of such companies (all with a track record of profit growth). It's free.

Have feedback on this article? Concerned about the content?Get in touch with us directly. Alternatively, email editorial-team (at) simplywallst.com.

This article by Simply Wall St is general in nature. We provide commentary based on historical data and analyst forecasts only using an unbiased methodology and our articles are not intended to be financial advice. It does not constitute a recommendation to buy or sell any stock, and does not take account of your objectives, or your financial situation. We aim to bring you long-term focused analysis driven by fundamental data. Note that our analysis may not factor in the latest price-sensitive company announcements or qualitative material. Simply Wall St has no position in any stocks mentioned.

View Comments

Next I will provide you some predictions of stock price movement probabilities and the corresponding analysis by others in the previous rounds.
Note that others' predictions may indicate that they have some other information about the stock price. A high prediction may indicate that they have some positive information about the stock, while a low prediction may indicate that they have some megative information about the stock.
Also note that there are multiple rounds of precitions, demonstrating the trend of others' beliefs.
Please take these information into consideration when prediction the stock price movement probabilities.
Previous predictions:
Round: 0
Model: openai/gpt-4o-mini, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.75, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.25, Reasoning: The news highlights Apple's conservative use of debt, showcasing a low net debt to EBITDA ratio and a strong interest coverage ratio. This suggests that Apple is in a solid financial position to manage its debt obligations, which is likely to instill confidence among investors. Additionally, the increase in EBIT and robust free cash flow further supports the notion that Apple can handle its liabilities effectively. Given these positive indicators, the probability of the stock price rising is higher than that of it falling.
Model: google/gemini-2.0-flash-001, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.65, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.35, Reasoning: The news article presents a positive view of Apple's debt management. It highlights that while Apple carries debt, its net debt is manageable due to its large cash reserves. Key positive indicators include a low net debt to EBITDA ratio, high interest coverage, and strong free cash flow generation. The article also mentions a slight increase in EBIT, further easing debt repayment concerns. While the article acknowledges potential risks outside the balance sheet, the overall tone suggests financial stability and prudent debt utilization. This positive assessment is likely to be viewed favorably by investors, potentially leading to a stock price increase. However, the article is not overwhelmingly bullish, and the market's reaction can be influenced by other factors not mentioned in the article. Therefore, a moderate probability of a stock price rise is assigned.
Model: google/gemini-flash-1.5, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.45, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.45, Reasoning: The news article focuses on Apple's conservative use of debt.  It highlights Apple's strong financial position, including substantial cash reserves, low net debt to EBITDA ratio, and high interest coverage.  The article concludes that Apple's debt levels are manageable and pose minimal risk. While acknowledging some general warnings (unspecified in the provided text), the overall tone is positive regarding Apple's financial health.  This positive assessment of Apple's financial strength is unlikely to significantly impact the stock price in the short term, as the information is largely consistent with existing market perceptions of Apple's financial stability.  Any price movement would likely be driven by other factors, such as broader market trends or specific product announcements. Therefore, the probabilities are weighted towards a neutral outcome.
Model: deepseek/deepseek-chat-v3-0324, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.7, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.1, Reasoning: The news article highlights Apple's conservative use of debt, noting that its net debt is manageable relative to its massive market capitalization and strong earnings. Key positive indicators include a low net debt to EBITDA ratio (0.31), high interest coverage (673x), and robust free cash flow generation (90% of EBIT). These factors suggest Apple is in a strong financial position to manage its liabilities and potentially reinvest for growth. The article also mentions a 7.8% increase in EBIT over the past year, further supporting the company's financial health. Given this positive outlook, the market is likely to react favorably to the news, reducing perceived risk and potentially driving the stock price higher.
Model: meta-llama/llama-4-scout, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.7, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.3, Reasoning: Apple Inc. (AAPL) seems to manage its debt quite conservatively, with a low net debt to EBITDA ratio of 0.31 and a significant ability to cover interest expenses with its EBIT. The company's ability to generate free cash flow and its robust EBIT coverage suggest that it can handle its debt obligations easily. These factors indicate a stable financial situation and potentially reduce the risk associated with its stock price. Given that Apple has a history of managing its debt conservatively and has a strong market position, the likelihood of its stock price rising appears to be higher than it falling. The company's ability to generate free cash flow and its low debt levels are positive indicators for its financial health.
Model: meta-llama/llama-3.3-70b-instruct, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.7, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.3, Reasoning: The news article suggests that Apple Inc. uses debt sparingly and has a low net debt to EBITDA ratio, indicating a healthy financial position. The company's ability to generate robust free cash flow and its strong market capitalization also contribute to its stable financial situation. Given this positive outlook, it is likely that the stock price will rise or remain stable rather than fall.

Model: google/gemini-flash-1.5, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.6, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.2, Reasoning: The news article focuses on Apple's conservative debt management, highlighting a low net debt to EBITDA ratio (0.31), high interest coverage (673x), and strong free cash flow generation (90% of EBIT).  These are all positive indicators of financial health and stability.  While the article acknowledges potential unspecified risks, the overall tone is very positive.  However, the information presented is largely consistent with existing market perceptions of Apple's financial strength.  Therefore, while the news is unlikely to cause a significant price drop, a substantial price increase is also unlikely in the short term. Considering the generally positive but not overwhelmingly bullish nature of the news, and the lack of any significant new information, I'm assigning a moderate probability to a price rise, with a relatively low probability of a price fall.
